subject: RE: [Fwd: Re: [junit] Propagating Exceptions]
msgSnippet: I have found that to be overkill. -Jason ... From: David Roussel [mailto:dir@bjss.co.uk] Sent: Wednesday, June 27, 2001 11:33 AM To: junit@yahoogroups.com
messageBody:
I have found that to be overkill.

-Jason

-----Original Message-----
From: David Roussel [mailto:dir@...]
Sent: Wednesday, June 27, 2001 11:33 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [Fwd: Re: [junit] Propagating Exceptions]


You could try using junit.extensions.ExceptionTestCase. I never used it
myself, but I can see it in the javadoc.
-----Original Message-----
From: Jason Rogers [mailto:jason.rogers@...]
Sent: 27 June 2001 12:26
To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
Subject: RE: [Fwd: Re: [junit] Propagating Exceptions]


IMO:
I would put an assert("<your message>", true) in here. You are basically
asserting that an unsupported action will fail! If it works, you have
passed the test, so an assert should go in.

-Jason

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Robert Sartin [mailto:sartin@...]
> Sent: Tuesday, June 26, 2001 5:01 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [Fwd: Re: [junit] Propagating Exceptions]
>
>
> /*
> --- Mike Duffy <mike.duffy@...> wrote:
> > Basically, the question was, "If you create a test
> method that calls
> > an updatePassword method and sends in an argument
> > that should throw an IllegalArgumentException, what do
> you put in the
> > catch block?"
>
> Unless the result of something else further testing, I
> would leave the
> catch empty as suggested:
> */
>
> public void testUnsupported() {
> try {
> objectUnderTest.doUnsupported();
> fail("doUnsupported did not throw exception");
> }
> catch (UnsupportedOperationException e) {
> // Pass
> }
> catch (Exception e) {
> fail("Wrong execption thrown by doUnsupported:" + e);
> }
>
> /*
> Regards,
>
> Rob
> */
>
>
